blocks.text: Essentials
Based on Radsource: "Not Plantaris: Keys to Better Diagnosis of Calf Strain Injuries."

items: Most calf strains are myotendinous junction tears of the medial head of the gastrocnemius, not isolated plantaris injury.
The medial head extends lower than the lateral head; the distal soleus extends a few centimeters further distal.
Aponeuroses form continuous arcing black lines on MRI; disruptions in continuity signal tears.
Axial imaging is critical; sagittal and coronal views are supportive but must be cross-referenced with axial slices.
Vessels can mimic aponeurosis defects-tracks are limited to 1-2 slices, lack adjacent edema, and connect fascia planes.

blocks.text: Plantaris & Calf Anatomy
Use these landmarks to avoid mistaking plantaris for the primary injury.

items: Plantaris tendon arises lateral to the lateral gastrocnemius, crosses medially, and descends along the medial margin of the Achilles tendon; sometimes absent or merges with the Achilles.

At upper calf levels the plantaris lies deep to the lateral gastrocnemius; mid-calf it courses between the medial gastrocnemius and soleus aponeuroses; distally it may be within or adjacent to the medial Achilles.
Soleus has multiple intramuscular tendons that can be strain sites; the posterior soleus aponeurosis lies just deep to the gastrocnemius aponeurosis.

blocks.text: Tear Patterns
Recognize characteristic aponeurotic configurations to describe extent.

items: L-pattern tear: Partial-width full-thickness transverse tear of the anterior gastrocnemius aponeurosis near the medial muscle margin with a vertical split along the lateral margin; the combined transverse and vertical components form an "L". The detached medial segment may retract.

U-pattern tear: Central transverse tear with vertical splits at both margins; the untethered segment bulges outward from hematoma. Typically partial-thickness, involving the aponeurosis and immediately underlying muscle with posterior muscle fibers intact.
Trace vertical tear length on axial images and correlate with coronal/sagittal images; edema usually tracks the full vertical extent.

Reading Checklist
A quick walkthrough for daily reads.

items: Start with axial images: follow continuity of anterior/posterior aponeuroses of gastrocnemius and soleus.
Locate the plantaris path; ensure a discrete plantaris is not misread as the primary tear.
Look for transverse gaps and adjacent vertical splits to classify L- or U-pattern tears.
Confirm tear extent on sagittal and coronal reformats; correlate with edema spread.
Exclude vessel perforators masquerading as defects (limited slices, no edema).
